data.title: Critical, Stable, or Fair: Defining Patient Conditions
data.meta_description: Critical condition, serious condition, stable: What do these terms  mean? Learn how hospitals describe patients' condition to the press and public.
data.text:
Weâve all seen a news report about someone who got rushed to the emergency room in âcriticalâ condition. Or read a more hopeful story about someone whoâs doing "fair" at the hospital. But what do those words really mean?

In the media, hospital terms that describe a patientâs condition -- like critical, fair, serious, stable -- are vague by design. They give you just a general sense of how someone is doing, which helps protect the patient's privacy.

In your personal life, a doctor or nurse at a hospital might use similar terms to tell you how an injured or sick loved one is doing. How much more detail they go into depends on things like your relationship with the person and the urgency of the situation.

Some hospitals use a standard set of one-word terms developed by the American Hospital Association (AHA) when they describe a patientâs condition to the press:

Undetermined

Good

Fair

Serious

Critical

But not all hospitals define these terms exactly the same way.

You might also hear the word âcriticalâ used to describe the type of treatment someone needs. People with life-threatening illnesses or injuries need critical care, usually in a hospitalâs intensive care unit (ICU).

If they need treatments to help them stay alive (called life support), they can also get those in the ICU. A few types of life support are:

A machine that helps you breathe, called a ventilator

Techniques to restart a stopped heart, like CPR and electric shocks (defibrillation)

Tube feeding to give you nutrients and hydration

Life support treatments don't necessarily mean a patient's condition is life-threatening. Sometimes doctors use them temporarily until the person is well enough to function on their own.

Instead, many hospitals just use the term âstableâ to describe when someoneâs vital signs are steady, or not changing much.

While itâs common for doctors to use the word stable to describe a patient whoâs in good condition, not everyone considers it to be that clear-cut. Since thereâs no agreed-upon medical definition for the word, some researchers say that one doctorâs idea of âstableâ might be anotherâs idea of âunstable.â

The bottom line is this: If you read or watch a news report that uses one word to describe a personâs condition, itâs meant to be general and vague. If you have a loved one in the hospital and their doctor or nurse explains their condition with a word thatâs not clear to you, ask them to explain what they mean. Donât feel bad about asking.
